DOC.HEAD: Batteries Fire at Unidentified Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: Anti-aircraft batteries opened fire late Tuesday at two unidentified aircraft that flew low over the capital, the government radio station Voice of Nicaragua reported. The radio broadcast said the control tower at the Augusto Cesar Sandino International Airport unsuccessfully tried to establish radio contact with the aircraft as they approached Managua from the north and the east before the batteries opened fire at about 9:30 p.m. The aircraft escaped, but the incident panicked residents of neighborhoods close to the airport as firing continued for several minutes and anti-aircraft tracers blew across the sky. The Sandinista government has placed the army on ``maximum alert'' since U.S. troops invaded Panama one week ago to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Earlier Tuesday, the Foreign Ministry said it was continuing efforts to arrange the evacuation of 156 Nicaraguan nationals from Panama. Most of the Nicaraguans were businesspeople, the ministry said. The government also sought to remove two aircraft operated by the national airline Aeronica that have been trapped at Panama City's Omar Torrijos airport since the invasion began.
